justification: “The two-step task putatively distinguishes between participants' tendency to utilise model-based versus model-free RL on a trial-by-trial basis.”
The same two-step paradigm yields separate parameters indexing the use of model-free RL strategies.
“Goal-directed behaviour is captured by sensitivity to outcome devaluation” in the selective devaluation procedure described by Friedel et al. (2014).
“Insensitivity to … outcome devaluation is a hallmark of habitual behaviour,” indicating that the devaluation paradigm is used to detect habits.

“Contingency learning … is often tested using contingency degradation, where an animal's behaviour is considered as goal-directed if its behaviour is sensitive to breakdowns in the action-outcome contingency.”
The review notes that “insensitivity to contingency degradation … is a hallmark of habitual behaviour,” showing this task indexes habits.

Sjoerds et al. (2016) “carried out … a ‘slips-of-action’ task that similarly measured sensitivity to outcome devaluation,” using it to assess the balance between goal-directed and habitual responding.
The authors recommend “adopting alternative tests of habit formation (e.g., Pavlovian-to-instrumental transfer task; Cartoni et al., 2016)” to capture habitual processes.
